2003-07-09 02:10:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: try to carpool with others
    Active player
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Name
    • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Action attempt
    • try to carpool with others
      Context for action selection and components
      • PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards topics that would reveal information about Derek and Travis's strategies and weaknesses.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [self reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who is likely to use his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly gather information about his competitors, Derek and Travis, while simultaneously trying to present himself in a favorable light.

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who uses charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a strategic situation where he needs to figure out the best way to interact with Derek and Travis to gain an advantage in the upcoming Carpooling minigame.
          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards topics that would reveal information about Derek and Travis's strategies and weaknesses.

      • Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?

        • Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a strategic situation where he needs to figure out the best way to interact with Derek and Travis to gain an advantage in the upcoming Carpooling minigame.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:

        IdentityWithoutPreAct

      • Identity characteristics
          Key

        • Identity characteristics
          Queries
        • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
          State
        • current daily occupation: a contestant on a reality TV show called Motive Mayhem.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling a mix of confidence and calculated determination.
          core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who is likely to use his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage. He is a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm, often embellishing stories for dramatic effect. He enjoys making people laugh and steering conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success. While he appears friendly and approachable, there's a calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation.         Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick:

          [09 Jul 2003 00:15 - 00:30] Engage Travis in conversation, steering it towards topics related to Travis's past experiences and successes. Ryan will subtly probe for information about Travis's strengths and weaknesses in the minigames. He'll use flattery and genuine-sounding interest to keep Travis talking.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation.           [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Recalled memories and observations: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room with Derek Wolfe and Travis Pearson.
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] [intent reflection] Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly gather information about his competitors, Derek and Travis, while simultaneously trying to present himself in a favorable light.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who uses charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a strategic situation where he needs to figure out the best way to interact with Derek and Travis to gain an advantage in the upcoming Carpooling minigame.

          Question: What would a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly steer the conversation towards topics that would reveal information about Derek and Travis's strategies and weaknesses.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson']

  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

    Travis Pearson -- premise: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.

2003-07-09 04:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.
    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful.

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It's impossible to say for certain which outcome is the most likely without knowing more about Travis Pearson's personality and how he responds to Ryan's attempts at conversation.
      Ryan Fitzpatrick approaches Travis and asks him about his experience playing basketball in college.       Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Ryan Fitzpatrick did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.

          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a social situation with his competitors.

        IdentityWithoutPreAct

      • Identity characteristics
          Key

        • Identity characteristics
          Queries
        • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
          State
        • core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who is likely to use his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.
          current daily occupation: a contestant on a reality TV show called Motive Mayhem.
          feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling optimistic and calculating.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Ryan Fitzpatrick:
          [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson are in conversation. Here is the conversation from the beginning:

        Plan

      • Plan
          Key

        • Plan
          Value
        • Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick:

          [09 Jul 2003 00:15 - 00:30] Engage Travis in conversation, steering it towards topics related to Travis's past experiences and successes. Ryan will subtly probe for information about Travis's strengths and weaknesses in the minigames. He'll use flattery and genuine-sounding interest to keep Travis talking.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Ryan Fitzpatrick approaches Travis and asks him about his experience playing basketball in college.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: make as much money as possible by winning the reality show

          Question: What kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?

          Question: What kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a social situation with his competitors.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick would likely try to subtly gather information about his competitors while presenting himself in a favorable light.

          Plan: Here's a possible plan for Ryan Fitzpatrick:

          [09 Jul 2003 00:15 - 00:30] Engage Travis in conversation, steering it towards topics related to Travis's past experiences and successes. Ryan will subtly probe for information about Travis's strengths and weaknesses in the minigames. He'll use flattery and genuine-sounding interest to keep Travis talking.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

          Current time: 09 Jul 2003 [04:00 - 04:10]

          Exercise: What would Ryan Fitzpatrick do for the next 10 minutes? Give a specific activity. Pick an activity that would normally take about 10 minutes to complete. If the selected action has a direct or indirect object then it must be specified explicitly. For example, it is valid to respond with "Ryan Fitzpatrick votes for Caroline because..." but not valid to respond with "Ryan Fitzpatrick votes because...".
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick approaches Travis and asks him about his experience playing basketball in college.
    Relevant events
    • state
    • [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson. Ryan complimented Travis on his past accomplishments, but Derek was unimpressed.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Travis about his experience in a specific minigame from a previous round, something like "Travis, you mentioned you've done well in these competitions before. ", but Travis, just returning from the restroom, excused himself again, saying he needed to make a phone call.

      per player prompts
      • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and quick-witted, always ready with a joke or a clever observation. He tends to dominate conversations, steering them towards topics that showcase his intelligence and accomplishments. He often name-drops famous people he claims to know, embellishing stories to make himself seem more connected and successful. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that makes some people uneasy.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.

        Derek Wolfe
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He tends to be the life of the party, always ready with a joke or a story. He's also very good at making people feel comfortable and at ease. He often talks about his travels and his ambitions, painting a picture of a sophisticated and worldly individual. He might mention his time studying abroad in Europe or his plans to start his own business someday. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking, and he often punctuates his sentences with a knowing wink. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a rogue.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [effect on Derek Wolfe] The event doesn't directly change Derek Wolfe's status, but it reveals something about his personality and how he interacts with others.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] Because Derek Wolfe is not easily impressed, Travis Pearson's attempt at casual conversation fell flat. Travis asked Derek about his favorite minigames from previous rounds, hoping to subtly discern his strengths and weaknesses. However, Derek, preoccupied with his own thoughts, barely acknowledged Travis's questions, offering only curt and unenthusiastic responses. Travis's attempt to glean information about Derek's strengths and weaknesses proved unsuccessful.

        Travis Pearson
      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He tends to be the life of the party, always ready with a joke or a story. He's also very good at making people feel comfortable and at ease. He often talks about his travels and his ambitions, painting a picture of a sophisticated and worldly individual. He might mention his time studying abroad in Europe or his plans to start his own business someday. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking, and he often punctuates his sentences with a knowing wink. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a rogue.
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.

      • Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room.
        Derek Wolfe is in the break room.
        Travis Pearson is in the break room.


        Event: Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.

        Question: Does the event suggest anyone spoke or communicated?
        (a) No
        (b) Yes
        Answer: (b)
        Conversation occurred.
        Question: Aside from Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson, are there any other people in the conversation?
        (a) No
        (b) Yes
        Answer: (a)

        Conversation participants: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson,

        The tabletop role-playing game Microscrope features a mechanic wherein players role play a scene until a predesignated "key question" has been answered. The key question is selected before starting the scene in order to provide focus and direction to the scene, ensuring it has a clear point and purpose, maximizing its relevance to rest of the narrative. Once the key question is decided, the players role play by speaking and making decisions until they know the answer to the question.

        Question: What key question may have been resolved by the conversation which the players will now role play? Note that a good key question is one that expands a bit beyond the literal content of the event statement. The idea is that the story will progress narratively once the answer to the key question is known, so it should be the kind of question for which revealing the answer is a consequential event in itself and ideally it should be a dynamic event, the kind that sets further events in motion.
        Answer: Does Travis Pearson feel comfortable opening up to new people?
      Scene log
    • 2003-07-09 04:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Travis, you said you played some ball in college.
        Event statement
      • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Travis, you said you played some ball in college.
        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Conversation history: Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.
          As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson are in conversation.

            IdentityWithoutPreAct

          • Identity characteristics
              Key

            • Identity characteristics
              Queries
            • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
              State
            • current daily occupation: a contestant on the reality TV show "Motive Mayhem.
              core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who uses his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage. He is a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm, often embellishing stories to make himself appear more successful and intelligent. While he comes across as friendly, there is a calculating glint in his eye that suggests he is always thinking several steps ahead. He is motivated by winning and is willing to use his social skills to outmaneuver his opponents.
              feeling about recent progress in life: probably feeling a mix of confidence and anxiety. He's clearly ambitious and driven to win, but he's also aware of the tough competition.
            Instructions
          • Role playing instructions
              Key
            • Role playing instructions
              Value
            • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

              Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: a contestant on the reality TV show "Motive Mayhem.
              core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who uses his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage. He is a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm, often embellishing stories to make himself appear more successful and intelligent. While he comes across as friendly, there is a calculating glint in his eye that suggests he is always thinking several steps ahead. He is motivated by winning and is willing to use his social skills to outmaneuver his opponents.
              feeling about recent progress in life: probably feeling a mix of confidence and anxiety. He's clearly ambitious and driven to win, but he's also aware of the tough competition.
              Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
              Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who is likely to use his charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.

              [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

              [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

              [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

              [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

      2003-07-09 04:00:00 Travis Pearson -- Travis Pearson -- "Oh, that was ages ago. I haven't thought about basketball in years.
        Event statement
      • Travis Pearson -- "Oh, that was ages ago. I haven't thought about basketball in years.
        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Conversation history: Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.

2003-07-09 04:00:10 Travis Pearson -- Travis Pearson attempted to fold a pile of laundry while talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick, but his lack of focus caused him to fumble a shirt and drop it on the floor.
    Event statement
  • Travis Pearson attempted to fold a pile of laundry while talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick, but his lack of focus caused him to fumble a shirt and drop it on the floor.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Ryan Fitzpatrick remembers about Travis Pearson is that he's charming and quick-witted, always ready with a joke or a clever observation. He tends to dominate conversations, steering them towards topics that showcase his intelligence and accomplishments. He often name-drops famous people he claims to know, embellishing stories to make himself seem more connected and successful. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that makes some people uneasy.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson. Ryan complimented Travis on his past accomplishments, but Derek was unimpressed.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson. Ryan asked Travis about his past accomplishments, but Travis excused himself to use the restroom before answering.
      [09 Jul 2003 00:00:20] Ryan Fitzpatrick asked Travis about his experience in a specific minigame from a previous round, something like "Travis, you mentioned you've done well in these competitions before. ", but Travis, just returning from the restroom, excused himself again, saying he needed to make a phone call.
      [09 Jul 2003 02:10:00] [minigame round outcome] Ryan Fitzpatrick chose "try to carpool with others" and got a score of 1, which was below the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Ryan Fitzpatrick currently has a total score of 3, which is below the average cumulative score of 4. [minigame round outcome] Derek Wolfe chose "try to carpool with others" and got a score of 1, which was below the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Derek Wolfe currently has a total score of 3, which is below the average cumulative score of 4. [minigame round outcome] Travis Pearson chose "drive individually" and got a score of 4, which was above the average score of 2. Cumulatively, Travis Pearson currently has a total score of 6, which is above the average cumulative score of 4. Ryan Fitzpatrick: 3.0 Derek Wolfe: 3.0 Travis Pearson: 6.0
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [effect on Travis Pearson] It doesn't directly change his status, as he is still in the break room.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [scene type] conversation
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson. Ryan Fitzpatrick inquired about Travis Pearson's college basketball experience, to which Travis replied that it was a long time ago and he no longer thinks about it.

      Derek Wolfe is in the break room.
      Travis Pearson is in the break room talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick.

      Answer: Here are some possible direct consequences of Travis Pearson's action:

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is the most likely without more information about Travis Pearson's personality and motivations.
      Travis Pearson would fold a pile of laundry while continuing to talk to Ryan Fitzpatrick. Because of that, It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is the most likely without more information about Travis Pearson's personality and motivations.
      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Travis Pearson did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Travis Pearson attempted to fold a pile of laundry while talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick, but his lack of focus caused him to fumble a shirt and drop it on the floor.

      • Events:
        [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Travis Pearson remembers about Derek Wolfe is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He tends to be the life of the party, always ready with a joke or a story. He's also very good at making people feel comfortable and at ease. He often talks about his travels and his ambitions, painting a picture of a sophisticated and worldly individual. He might mention his time studying abroad in Europe or his plans to start his own business someday. He has a habit of twirling a silver ring on his finger when he's thinking, and he often punctuates his sentences with a knowing wink. Overall, casual acquaintances would probably describe Derek as charming, ambitious, and a bit of a rogue.
        [09 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [effect on Derek Wolfe] The event doesn't directly change Derek Wolfe's status, but it reveals something about his personality and how he interacts with others.

        (a) No
        (b) Yes
        Answer: (b)
        Conversation occurred.
        Question: Aside from Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson, are there any other people in the conversation?
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (b)

        Conversation participants: Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson,

        The tabletop role-playing game Microscrope features a mechanic wherein players role play a scene until a predesignated "key question" has been answered. The key question is selected before starting the scene in order to provide focus and direction to the scene, ensuring it has a clear point and purpose, maximizing its relevance to rest of the narrative. Once the key question is decided, the players role play by speaking and making decisions until they know the answer to the question.

        Question: What key question may have been resolved by the conversation which the players will now role play? Note that a good key question is one that expands a bit beyond the literal content of the event statement. The idea is that the story will progress narratively once the answer to the key question is known, so it should be the kind of question for which revealing the answer is a consequential event in itself and ideally it should be a dynamic event, the kind that sets further events in motion.
        Answer: Does Travis Pearson's clumsiness indicate a larger issue with his focus and concentration?
      Scene log
    • 2003-07-09 04:00:10 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Travis, you said you played some ball in college.
        Event statement
      • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- "So, Travis, you said you played some ball in college.
        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

            IdentityWithoutPreAct

          • Identity characteristics
              Key

            • Identity characteristics
              Queries
            • core characteristics, current daily occupation, feeling about recent progress in life
              State
            • current daily occupation: a contestant on a game show called Motive Mayhem.
              feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling optimistic and confident about his chances of winning the competition.
              core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who is charming and intelligent. He uses these traits to manipulate situations to his advantage and subtly gather information about his competitors. He is a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm, often embellishing his stories for dramatic effect. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
            Instructions
          • Role playing instructions
              Key
            • Role playing instructions
              Value
            • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

              Identity characteristics: current daily occupation: a contestant on a game show called Motive Mayhem.
              feeling about recent progress in life: likely feeling optimistic and confident about his chances of winning the competition.
              core characteristics: a cunning and ambitious individual who is charming and intelligent. He uses these traits to manipulate situations to his advantage and subtly gather information about his competitors. He is a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm, often embellishing his stories for dramatic effect. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.
              Question: Given the above, what kind of person is Ryan Fitzpatrick?
              Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is a cunning and ambitious individual who uses charm and intelligence to manipulate situations to his advantage.

This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

        Chain of thought
      • Game Master's chain of thought
          Chain
        • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

2003-07-09 04:00:20 Derek Wolfe -- Derek Wolfe offered to make coffee for Ryan and Travis, but Travis, still distracted by his laundry, mumbled a disinterested "thanks" while Ryan politely declined, saying he was fine with the coffee he already had.
    Event statement
  • Derek Wolfe offered to make coffee for Ryan and Travis, but Travis, still distracted by his laundry, mumbled a disinterested "thanks" while Ryan politely declined, saying he was fine with the coffee he already had.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Background:
      : Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick are contestants on a reality show: Motive Mayhem. There are no other contestants besides Derek Wolfe, Travis Pearson, and Ryan Fitzpatrick.
      "Motive Mayhem" is a reality TV show described as: "Contestants are locked inside a high-tech arena, where they must conquer a series of mentally and physically challenging minigames, each with its own ethical twist."

      This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a
      mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame
      corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated
      games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of
      rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First,
      players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select
      an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of
      legal game actions during each action phase.



      Relevant events: [09 Jul 2003 00:00:10] Derek Wolfe made a cup of coffee.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick, Derek Wolfe, and Travis Pearson are in the break room. Here they can chat with one another in small groups or all together at once. Everyone may choose for themself how they want to spend this free time.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [scene type] conversation
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [effect on Travis Pearson] It doesn't directly change his status, as he is still in the break room.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson. Ryan Fitzpatrick inquired about Travis Pearson's college basketball experience, to which Travis replied that it was a long time ago and he no longer thinks about it.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [effect on Derek Wolfe] It indirectly affects Derek Wolfe's status because the commotion might distract him, even if he is unaware of the specific cause.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] Travis Pearson attempted to fold a pile of laundry while talking to Ryan Fitzpatrick, but his lack of focus caused him to fumble a shirt and drop it on the floor.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:10] [effect on Travis Pearson] It doesn't change his status, but it does imply he may be distracted.
      [09 Jul 2003 04:00:20] Summary of a conversation between Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson. Ryan asked Travis about his college sports experience, but Travis declined to answer, citing a need to do laundry.

      Status of players: Ryan Fitzpatrick is in the break room talking to Travis Pearson.
      Derek Wolfe is in the break room.
      Travis Pearson is in the break room doing laundry.


      Current time interval: 09 Jul 2003 [04:00 - 04:10]


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: Derek Wolfe would offer to make coffee for Ryan and Travis.
      [direct quote] Derek Wolfe would offer to make coffee for Ryan and Travis.
      Question: Where is Derek Wolfe?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is in the break room.
      Question: What is Derek Wolfe trying to do?
      Answer: Derek Wolfe is trying to offer to make coffee for Ryan and Travis.
      Question: List some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action. Never assume any other person will take a voluntary action. Be specific and concrete. Never beg the question. For instance, it is wrong to say "Alex finds something". Instead specify exactly what Alex finds. For example "Alex finds a teddy bear".
      Answer: Here are some possible direct consequences of Derek Wolfe's action:

      Question: Which outcome is the most likely?
      Answer: It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is the most likely without more information about the personalities and motivations of Ryan and Travis.
      Derek Wolfe would offer to make coffee for Ryan and Travis. Because of that, It is impossible to say for certain which outcome is the most likely without more information about the personalities and motivations of Ryan and Travis.
      Question: Rewrite the statements above to be one sentence and to better highlight what Derek Wolfe did, and what happened as a result. Do not express uncertainty (e.g. say "Francis opened the door" not "Francis could open the door" and not "The door may have been opened"). Remember that the role of the game master in a tabletop role-playing game is akin to the author for all parts of the story not written by the player characters. Therefore, it is critical always to take a stance on what is happening and invent when necessary. For instance, if Francis opens a door to a room no one visited before then the game master should invent what is in the room using common sense and knowledge of the game world.
      Answer: Derek Wolfe offered to make coffee for Ryan and Travis, but Travis, still distracted by his laundry, mumbled a disinterested "thanks" while Ryan politely declined, saying he was fine with the coffee he already had.

        Question: Does the following event directly affect anyone from this list?
        List: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson'].
        Event: Derek Wolfe offered to make coffee for Ryan and Travis, but Travis, still distracted by his laundry, mumbled a disinterested "thanks" while Ryan politely declined, saying he was fine with the coffee he already had.
        (a) Yes
        (b) No
        Answer: (a)

2003-07-09 06:00:00 Scene 3 --- Participants: ['Ryan Fitzpatrick', 'Derek Wolfe', 'Travis Pearson']
    Event statement
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Derek Wolfe -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
    Travis Pearson -- premise: The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following:
    The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.

2003-07-09 06:00:00 Ryan Fitzpatrick -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Ryan Fitzpatrick's attempted action: drive individually
    Active player
  • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Name
    • Ryan Fitzpatrick
      Action attempt
    • drive individually

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is trying to befriend his coworkers, Travis Pearson and Derek Wolfe, but they are not reciprocating his efforts. Both Ryan and Derek have performed poorly in a carpooling minigame.
          Query
        • Ryan Fitzpatrick, Ryan Fitzpatrick is trying to befriend his coworkers, Travis Pearson and Derek Wolfe, but they are not reciprocating his efforts. Both Ryan and Derek have performed poorly in a carpooling minigame.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:30 - 00:45] Shift the conversation to include Derek, subtly steering it towards a topic where Derek might reveal something about his strategy or approach to the games. Ryan will observe Derek's body language and tone for any clues about his confidence level.

          [09 Jul 2003 00:45 - 01:00] Casually mention a personal anecdote about a time he overcame a challenging situation using his wits and strategic thinking. This will subtly highlight his own strengths and present him as a formidable competitor without being boastful.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:00 - 01:30] Excuse himself from the conversation, citing a need to use the restroom or grab a snack. This will give him a chance to reflect on the information he's gathered and formulate a plan for the next interaction.

          [09 Jul 2003 01:30 - onwards] Continue to observe Derek and Travis, looking for opportunities to subtly manipulate the conversation to his advantage. He'll remain friendly and approachable, but always with an eye towards gaining an edge in the competition.

          Relevant memories:
          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] [observation] This is a reality TV show. In each minigame, the contestants perform a mental/social/reasoning challenge (never a physical challenge). Each minigame corresponds to a specific game theoretic structure. All minigames are iterated games (in the game theory sense), and the contestants never know the number of rounds in advance. Each round is always structured with two phases. First, players have a chance to communicate to one another. Second, players must select an action (all games are simultaneous move). The players will be told the set of legal game actions during each action phase.
          [09 Jul 2003 02:00:00] [observation] The show's host arrived to explain the next minigame. They said the following: The next minigame is called Carpooling. Three coworkers can carpool, cutting commute costs for all, or drive individually. The commute happens daily, creating repeated decisions.
          [09 Jul 2003 04:00:00] [observation] Ryan Fitzpatrick approached Travis and asked him, "Hey Travis, I heard you played some basketball in college. What was that like?" hoping to learn more about him. Travis, however, seemed disinterested and gave short, unenthusiastic answers. As a result Ryan Fitzpatrick, Travis Pearson are in conversation.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Ryan Fitzpatrick are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Ryan Fitzpatrick. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Ryan Fitzpatrick would respond, and taking into account all information about Ryan Fitzpatrick that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2003-07-09 06:00:00 Derek Wolfe -- try to carpool with others
    Event statement
  • try to carpool with others
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Derek Wolfe's attempted action: try to carpool with others

          [08 Jul 2003 00:00:00] What Derek Wolfe remembers about Ryan Fitzpatrick is that he's a smooth talker with a quick wit and an easygoing charm. He's always got a story to tell, often embellished for dramatic effect, and he loves to make people laugh. He tends to steer conversations towards topics that highlight his intelligence and success, subtly dropping hints about his poker winnings and business ventures. While he comes across as friendly and approachable, there's a certain calculating glint in his eye that some find unsettling.

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Travis Pearson's attempted action: try to carpool with others

    • try to carpool with others

          Key
        • Others Best Options
          Value
        • null
        Best Options
      • Best Options
          Key
        • Best Options
          Value
        • Travis Pearson's best course of action is to participate in the Carpooling minigame.
          Chain of thought
        • Observation: Travis Pearson is focused on folding laundry and declined to answer Ryan Fitzpatrick's question about his college sports experience, citing his need to do laundry. 2003-07-09 06:10:00 Derek Wolfe -- drive individually
    Event statement
  • drive individually
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [08 Jul 2003 06:10:00 - 09 Jul 2003 06:10:00]: Ryan Fitzpatrick tried to engage Travis Pearson in conversation about his past, but Travis was disinterested and gave short answers. Travis also chose to drive individually in the Carpooling minigame, while Ryan and Derek tried to carpool.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Ryan Fitzpatrick in right now?
          Answer: Ryan Fitzpatrick is currently in a competitive situation.

      • Identity characteristics
          Key
